column4: I know this isn't an ubuntu question... but it involves ubuntu... I'm trying to use google picasa from ubuntu all my pics are on a USB drive attached to my networked windows box which is also shared and I read awhile back that picasa can read from networked drives, a share is not necessarily a network drive correct?
if I understand correctly... I would have to map that network share/drive?
to do that how would I do that in ubuntu?
better yet, the real question is, how do I map a network drive?
hold on
cool ty, take ur time
http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=216087
well picasa won't looka t network shares... so it has to be a drive letter
I'd like to try the GUI way of doing it anyway, I'm anti CLI
You're not going to be able to map a network "drive", as Linux doesn't have a concept of such things.
is there any info on doing this the GUI way?
oh
I know windows does... but I also noticed that picasa doesn't see C:\filesystem as you said it doesn't have the concept of drive letters
It's been ages since I've used Ubuntu's GNOME interface, but it's one of the options in the center menu.  I think it's called "Connect to remote computer" or such.
I just need to mount a network drive... drive letters are irrelevant as picasa won't look at network shares
The GUI way of doing it is only going to appear in Nautilus, IIRC.  But I could be wrong.
I guess we'll find out, I think thats what we want... whatever nautilus sees so will picasa
The "Connect to remote computer" allows you to set up a virtual folder that lets you access the files on an FTP server, SSH server or Windows computer.
It's a catch-all for remote filesystems.
I don't understand though... when I log into the windows share, the volume is automatically mounted on the desktop... isn't that enough?
Picasa is based on WINE, which is based off of the fundamental Linux filesystem.  IIRC, "Connect to Server" creates a virtual filesystem which is only visible within GNOME.
would it be "connect to server"?
So, yes.
It uses winelib, which is basically a library that lets you compile Windows applications on Linux.
